我最强的能力可能是我真正关心事物。好的，我正在写这篇文章：)
我的第二个最重要的能力可能是我很谦虚。在德语中，我们称之为“Tugend der Beschedenheit”。我强烈希望不是用我说的话来说服人们，而是用我实际做的事情来说服人们。对于招聘流程来说，这可能是一个弱点。我从一位美国朋友那里得到了以下反馈：“托比，请不要那么谦虚。你是我见过的最聪明的人之一。“=&gt；聪明人不喜欢自吹自擂可能是一个共同的性格特征。
我非常不擅长记忆和复制“常见的、已经解决的问题”，但擅长在新的环境和未知领域跟上进度。相信我，41年过去了，我仍然没有弄清楚这两个性格特征到底是如何相互依赖的，但它们之间肯定有很强的联系。意识到这一点，我选择了专注于Javascript，因为这是一个变化速度令人难以置信的领域。当我深入到新的领域时，我经常会达到一个水平，大多数开发人员都不能再跟我走了。这既是好事，也是坏事。
我极具好奇心、热情、上进心和事业心。在某种程度上，它不再被认为是“健康的”。我喜欢跳出框框思考。
在PlayStation项目之后，我自我反省了一段时间，得出的结论是，我想坚持UI领域，因为我非常喜欢创建“下一个级别”的UI/App。由于我对当前的UI库/框架环境非常不满，我以前的“解决方案工程师心态”再次发挥作用。
我在这个项目上花了两年的全额和无薪工作时间，对改善UI开发的总体工作方式产生了严重的影响。我原本计划在今年的会议上展示“NEO”，但多亏了新冠肺炎，这已经不可能了。由于ne.mjs是“颠覆性的”，→要求开发人员具有好奇心，并且潜心于新概念，所以它还没有得到我所希望的吸引力。
在烧掉了我大部分的个人积蓄之后，我实际上对新的项目，甚至是一个全职角色都是敞开大门的。由于框架已经准备好投入生产，因此我更喜欢能够实际使用它来产生业务价值的角色。在这一点上，使用诸如角度、反应或Vue之类的“主流库”只会减慢我的速度。这感觉就像是剪下一只鸟的翅膀，然后期待它飞起来。
我不知道这个过程是否真的是为了“聘请最好的人”，或者这只是一个纯粹的营销骗局。
简而言之：“每个被录用的人都应该比目前担任类似职位的人中的50%更好。”
“我猜所有的公司都抱有很高的期望，都想达到那个高门槛。这只会扼杀招聘人员，并限制我们可以聘用的应聘者。“。
(在10年前加入Sencha→之前，我就在FB招聘过程中，甚至在Reaction出现之前。这花了太长时间，Sencha听起来更适合我目前的技能。)。
在员工不断学习、不断进步的假设下，这句话给年轻一代带来了极大的压力。
在我看来，这个概念不可能长期可持续。
你可能会争辩说，一些优秀的员工会跳槽或退休，但这并不能弥补这一点，以防公司想要继续增长。
虽然这对于非技术角色来说可能听起来很新鲜&令人兴奋，但对于在敏捷环境中工作时间较长的开发人员来说，大多数项目都是琐碎的，而且无论如何都是每天都要做的事情。
“有骨气；不同意和承诺”这一项在面试中肯定不被赏识。)。
公平地说，FB的招聘过程(10年前)几乎是我经历过的最后一次“真正”的招聘过程。直到今天我才知道它有多大的进步。做这件事的时候，花的时间太长了。我已经从Sencha那里拿到了一份合同，在完全探索之前，它已经准备好要签了。
回到森查，成为第一位德国全职员工，这是一次愉快的经历。由于我事先已经使用了ExtJS框架的增强功能达到了专业水平，所以在技术方面没有什么可谈的。不管怎么说，公司的理念是“招人才，教技能”。或者，用PS团队的领导的话说：“雇佣优秀的工程师，确保不要妨碍他们。”从人力资源的角度来看：“托比，只要你每年创造50万美元的收入，我们对你很满意。”嗯，这个有点争议，因为它依赖于你的经理让你参与客户项目，但我可以接受。
PlayStation团队的体验甚至更好。公平地说，这只是一份“长期承包商协议”，而不是一个全职角色。我收到一封电子邮件，问我是否有兴趣帮助他们。我们打了一个电话，讨论了他们的想法，以及这与我的技能组合是如何匹配的。我们在第一次通话中就创造了业务价值。
不要在毫无意义的管理费用上浪费应聘者或公司的时间。开门见山吧。动作快点。
我的流程始于6月4日，一名AWS内部招聘人员找到我，询问我是否有兴趣为AWS在柏林领导一个新的UI团队。这让我很好奇他们打算在那里做什么，以及这是否适合我目前的技能。所以我同意把我的简历寄给人力资源部。招聘人员做得很好，与他交流很愉快。如今，真正阅读潜在应聘者个人资料并撰写个性化介绍的招聘者极为罕见。
作为下一步，我得到了一些关于招聘过程的总体意见。简而言之：“将有2次远程面试。如果我们两个都很喜欢的话，每个人还会有5-6.1h的加班费。假设你到了那里，我们建议你准备5-6个星期的考试，至少整整两个星期。“。
我意识到，在这一点上，被问到我是否感兴趣是没有意义的，我被拖入了标准的招聘流程。我的“好奇心”开始发挥作用，我很感兴趣地想看看他们的“聘用最好的人”的过程在现实生活中会是什么样子。
我被要求使用在线表格输入第一次远程面试的首选日期。在这张表格里，你可以选择任何时间和日期(如果我没记错的话，从当天的前3天开始)。缺少的部分是表单/日历视图应该显示每个地区的可用时间范围，理想情况下应该阻止不可用的时间，以防万一。
我只是选择了整个下周从下午2点到晚上10点的CEST，因为我不确定电话是否会以美国为基地。我得到的答复是，CEST的面试时间是上午10点到下午5点，并被要求输入新的日期。我想“好吧，这样连续5天只剩下3个小时了”，但我还是在在线日历中调整了我喜欢的日期。没有“编辑”按钮，因此根本不可能更改它们(功能请求！)。
我回复了一封电子邮件，我可以让它发生在下周上午10点开始，如果这会让他们的事情变得更容易的话。我得到的回应是，下周内根本没有空位，并获得了6月22日星期一的一个空位。如果日历视图刚刚向我显示下一周已经被阻止(功能请求！)，这种通信开销本可以很容易地避免。
我的第一个面试电话非常友好和专业。面试官给人留下了深刻的印象。缺点是，在没有签署保密协议的情况下，他不能告诉我任何关于新球队的事情。
像这样的问题：“自从近地天体项目上线以来，其他人是否对该项目做出了重大贡献？”或者“如果现在使用它的开发人员还不多，您怎么能确定是正确的方式呢？”
嗯，这确实很好地符合领导原则：“因为我们做新的事情，所以我们接受我们可能会在很长一段时间内被误解的事实。”我喜欢面试官真的调查了我的项目。
一天后，6月23日，星期二，我收到了一封电子邮件：“团队在第一次谈话后分享了非常积极的反馈，并希望安排第二次电话面试。”我被要求在接下来的3周内为第二轮选择我喜欢的日期。我在同一天回复说，周五(6月26日)和接下来的整个一周一样有效。最初的第二轮电子邮件包含这样的信息，即第二轮将再次与领导原则有关。
6月26日，我收到了一封包含“亚马逊SDE面试准备”的电子邮件。这份文档简直就是一个时髦的词--一大堆(！)。你在学习计算机科学时接触到的项目。初级角色和高级角色之间完全没有区别，最重要的是，与前端和后端相关的角色之间也没有区别。需要明确的是：对于与前端相关的角色来说，大多数项目都没有任何意义。因此，这可能是我最大的特性要求：请更详细地了解这一点。我在10-15年前确实知道很多提到的项目，但那些我后来在现实生活项目中从未需要的项目现在已经不存在了。我马上回复了一封电子邮件(同一天，→，星期五，6月26日)，再次检查我的面试是否与前端相关，得到的回复是肯定的。由于NDA的原因，不可能共享真实的输入，因此准备文档的值几乎为零。我还提到，我还没有得到我对第二轮的首选日期的反馈。我问我们是否应该在第二轮签署保密协议，得到的回答是“不，这不需要。”意思是：“我们不想为您提供任何您可能感兴趣的信息。”
7月3日星期五，我仍然没有收到关于第二轮面试的首选日期。我建议的日期此时已经过去，其中包括在CEST可用面试时间内的42小时。我知道人力资源部的员工可能有很多事情要做，但邀请我参加第二轮面试后完全没有回应，感觉非常不专业。应该有一个候选人数据库到位，自动提醒在一个合理的时间框架内回应。
在整个过程进行了整整一个月后，总结我的经验：1)在这一点上，我仍然没有第二轮的日期，我甚至不知道他们是否还想这样做。2)我被期望从慕尼黑搬到柏林，以防这个过程会成功。3)有人问我是否有兴趣领导一个新的UI团队，但对它的任务仍然一无所知(除了“我们想要创建下一代开发工具”，这可能是几乎任何事情)。4)我不知道它是否适合我目前的技能，或者涵盖了我感兴趣的主题。5)我没有得到关于新UI团队规模的任何意见(这个团队对我来说很重要，因为在一个小团队中我可以继续自己开发，这是我非常喜欢的)。6)我没有输入开始日期。7)我没有得到与工资相关的信息。
有点单薄，你不同意吗？我的动机已经接近于零了。
在这一点上，我已经拒绝了另一家公司的报价。6位数的公司股票，但内容不是特别有趣。
在我有时间进行第二轮工作的这一周里，我收到了一封电子邮件，要求我就亚马逊的招聘流程提供反馈。我也在那里进入了本文部分的大部分内容。
在我喜欢的日期过后的周一早上，我收到了一封来自亚马逊的电子邮件：
在亚马逊寻找求职机会的潜在候选人时，我们在一个公开的求职网站上找到了您的个人资料。基于您的专业背景，我们认为您可能非常适合亚马逊的工作机会，并已将您的详细信息添加到我们的候选人关系管理系统(“CRM系统”)中。这样，我们的内部招聘团队将能够在亚马逊有我们认为您可能感兴趣的工作机会时通知您。…“。
嗯，看起来招聘团队和人力资源团队使用的不是同一个数据库：)。
我们很高兴确认您与亚马逊网络服务公司的电话采访日期：2020年7月7日星期二时间：12：00 pm-1：00 pm(CEST)。
没有为12天没有联系以及忽略我喜欢的约会而道歉。希望我能在第二天打个电话。
我回信再次确认第二轮是关于领导原则(就像在最初的第二轮电子邮件中提到的那样)，还是关于准备文件(可能是为了在之后的5-6次面试中使用)。
第二次面试对我来说就像一个笑话。我的面试官给人的印象是一个招聘经验很少的初级开发人员。我问他在通话前是否看过我的近地天体项目，得到的回答是“没有”。我告诉他，我的最新代码有50.000多行，涵盖了几乎所有关于架构、设计模式和算法的主题，并问他，我们是否应该做一个简短的5-10米的介绍，以了解我的能力。“不，这只是一个开源项目。如果我愿意，我可以稍后再看一看。“。
这清楚地表明，面试官对我的专业技能完全不感兴趣，对我的好奇心几乎为零。这也让人觉得非常傲慢，因为我非常肯定他没有简短的自我介绍是无法理解的。
相反，我的“挑战”(LOL)是展示我将如何重新创建类似Google Analytics的东西。我的回答是，我会创建一个可以包含在应用程序中的脚本。加载后，它既可以使用WebSocket，也可以通过Ajax调用传输数据。我只需将一个全局单击侦听器添加到Document.body，然后发送委托的“JSONalized”事件路径(或ID&amp；CSS规则→任何足够好的东西，以便在单击发生的位置有一个标识符)。我们可以为Mousemove事件添加缓冲，以防它们相关。我得到的回应是，这是不够的，因为他们可以使用WebComponents，而影子dom是“禁区”。实际上并非如此，因为您可以在影子根目录上使用模式：“open”config来避免这种情况。感觉就像我在那里把他弄丢了(甚至后来用谷歌搜索了一下，我是对的)。我还补充说，如果这是不可能的，我们可以只在框架/库呈现逻辑中创建挂钩，并为每个Web组件添加单独的单击侦听器。
这一次我更聪明了，我问道，如果不可能再告诉我任何事情，我是否至少可以在他们心目中的UI技术堆栈上获得一些输入。我听到了一些时髦的话，但并不令人印象深刻。
7月8日，星期三，我收到一封电子邮件：“在仔细考虑和审查您的申请之后，我们决定与其他应聘者一起申请这个职位。虽然我们不能就这一决定提供更多的反馈或信息，但我们愿意就未来的就业机会保持联系。“。
也许是最好的结果，因为我认为进入下一轮还需要2周以上的时间，再一次不提供任何输入，并且做更多毫无意义的测试。
我知道，我们处在新冠肺炎时代，HR团队有很多事情要做。尽管如此，忽视包含问题的电子邮件仍然是令人难以置信的不专业。创建工具，以防它们不存在，以跟踪与候选人的沟通情况。添加一个大红旗&amp；提醒，以防无响应。
如果你没有时间，就写一封简短的电子邮件，让应聘者知道这件事。比如：“对不起，我们现在忙得不可开交，但我们下周会给你回电的。”
虽然大公司可以允许自己有点傲慢(他们真的不应该这样做)，因为它们确实收到了很多申请，但如果它们利用招聘人员来接触潜在的候选人，特别是高级职位，情况就不同了。
我与许多以前的同事交谈过，他们中的大多数人如果有这个小小的投入，他们中的大多数人就会更早地退出这一过程。否则，你将失去大多数最优秀的候选人。
你不能指望应聘者提供大量的投入、测试和努力，而不给予回报。为什么有人要在不知道为什么的情况下投入大量的时间呢？
到目前为止，我已经与全球的&gt；2000开发人员合作过。我非常熟悉自己的长处和短处。相信我，5-10年前情况并非如此。特别是对于那些在招聘过程中全身心投入的初级开发人员来说，“虽然我们不能就这一决定提供额外的反馈或信息”这样的声明可能是毁灭性的。这也是非常不公平的，因为你没有给候选人提升自己的机会。
我的父母都是老师，所以我对学习经验有一定的了解。一个常见的面试问题是例如。
我们的目标是在总体上检查候选人是否能够承认错误(这是一件好事)。你还可以检查应聘者是否从错误中吸取教训并变得更好。“尝试和失败”是一个合理的方法，特别是在你确实学习和提高的情况下。
另一方面，特别是在某一特定领域长期工作时，掌握自己的专长是绝对有可能的。您意识到了技术债务，您设计开发路线图的方式是将持续重构保持在高优先级。
如果候选人电话。

This article is meant for recruiters, people working in HR as well as candidates. I think that there is the need for a significant change.
    This article is controversial and you might not agree with my perspective in all points. You are welcome to add comments and start a discussion. My intention is not to highlight problems or express my personal frustration, but as a former Solutions Engineer to provide input and possible solutions on how to improve the process of hiring talented candidates.
 I have been talking about this topic with many former colleagues & recruiters and most of them agreed that the way standardised processes work is neither good for candidates nor for companies. This does not only affect Amazon, but other big companies like Apple, Facebook & Google as well.
  I am 41 years old and am working with Javascript for 20 years now. I always had a very strong focus on UI development, especially for very large & complex Apps (performance, custom components, scalable & modular architectures).
 The 2 previous roles which influenced my professional career as well as my personal growth the most:
 I joined the Sencha Professional Services Team for 2.5 years in November 2011. Sencha was at its peak and the PS team was kept intentionally way too small: 8 experts to cover 5000+ clients world wide. My job felt like a Firefighter: jumping into projects which were completely on fire and fixing the most pressing issues right away (framework & app related), as well as scheduling new roadmaps, creating new design patterns & architectures. I was basically living in airplanes, being not at home for 62% of my time (including weekends). I also helped out in the Trainings Team & got speaker invites for several conferences. I helped clients like Accenture, Air Asia, Bouygoues Telecom, Citibank, HSBC and many others.
 Afterwards I helped the Sony PlayStation Team for 4.5 years to create the UI of a management perspective for their game development (from inception, over development (connecting game studios), until the global distribution with connected franchise partners). The project went incredibly smooth. It got started using the Sencha Ext JS framework with a massive amount of overrides & enhancements to make it work for this use case. Since Ext JS turned out to be a dead end (long story), we reviewed Angular, React & Vue and came to the conclusion, that these libraries / frameworks are not sufficient to work on a professional basis.
    My probably strongest ability is that I actually care about things. Well, I am writing this article :)
 My probably second most important ability is that I am humble. In German, we call this “Tugend der Bescheidenheit”. I strongly prefer to not convince people with the things I say, but with the things I actually do. For hiring processes, this can be a weakness. I got the following feedback from an American friend: “Tobi, please stop being so damn humble. You are one of the most intelligent guys I have ever met.” => It might be a common character trait for intelligent people to dislike praising themselves.
 I am extremely bad at memorising things & reproducing “common, already solved problems”, but excel at getting up to speed in new environments & unknown areas. Trust me, after 41 years I still have not figured out how exactly those 2 character traits rely on each other, but there definitely is a strong relationship. Being aware of this, I picked focussing on Javascript, since this is an area which changes at an incredible speed. When deeply diving into new areas, I have often reached a level, where most developers are no longer able to follow me. This is good & bad at the same time.
 I am extremely curious, passionate, self motivated & driven. Up to a point, where it is no longer considered as being “healthy”. I love to think outside the box.
 After the PlayStation project, I was self-reflecting for a while and came to the conclusion, that I want to stick to the UI area, since I deeply enjoy creating “next level” UIs / Apps. Since I was most definitely unhappy with the current UI library / framework landscape, my former “Solutions Engineer mentality” kicked in once more.
   I spent 2 years of my full & unpaid working time on this project, to make a serious impact improving the way UI development works in general. My original plan was to present “neo” at conferences this year, but thanks to Covid-19, this is no longer possible. Since neo.mjs is “disruptive” → requires devs to be curious & dive into new concepts, it has not yet got the traction I was hoping for.
 After burning most of my personal savings on it, I am actually open for new projects or even a full time role. Since the framework is ready to get into production, I would prefer roles where I can actually use it to generate business value. At this point, using “mainstream libs” like Angular, React or Vue would just slow me down. This would feel like clipping the wings of a bird and then expect it to fly.
  I am not sure if the process is actually aiming to “hire the best”, or if it is just a plain marketing hoax.
   In short:  “Every person hired should be better than 50 percent of those currently in similar roles.”
     “I guess all companies have high hopes and want to attain that high bar. It just kills the Recruiters and limits the pool of candidates we can engage.”
 (I was inside the FB hiring process before joining Sencha → 10 years ago, before React even existed. It took way too long and Sencha sounded like a better fit for my skill set at this point in time.)
 With the assumption that employees keep learning & are getting better, this quote puts an extreme amount of pressure on the younger generation.
 In my opinion it is impossible that the concept can be sustainable on the long run.
 You could argue that some great employees switch companies or retire, but this does not compensate it, in case a company wants to continue growing.
   While this might sound new & exciting for non technical roles, for developers working in agile environments for a longer time, most items are trivial and lived on a daily basis anyway.
 The item “Have Backbone; Disagree and Commit” is most definitely not appreciated in interviews ;)
  To be fair, the FB hiring process (10 years ago), was pretty much the last “real” hiring process i experienced. I don’t know how much it has improved until today. When doing it, it took way too long. I already got a contract from Sencha, which was ready to get signed, before fully exploring it.
 Joining Sencha back in the days as the first German full time employee was a pleasant experience. Since I already reached a professional level using & enhancing the Ext JS framework beforehand, there was not much to talk about on the technical side of things. The philosophy was “ Hire talent, teach skill” anyway. Or, how the leader of the PS team put it: “ Hire excellent engineers & make sure to not stand in their way.”. From an HR perspective: “Tobi, as long as you generate > $500k in income per year, we are happy with you.”. Well, this one was a bit controversial, since it relies on your managers putting you on client projects, but I could live with it.
 The PlayStation Team experience was even better. To be fair, this one was just a “long term contractor agreement” and not a full time role. I got an email, asking if I was interested in helping them. We did a call and talked about what they have in mind and how this matches my skill set. We created  business value inside the very first call.
  Don’t waste the time of candidates or companies with pointless overhead. Get to the point. Do it fast.
   My process started on June 4th with an internal AWS recruiter reaching out to me and asking if I would be interested in leading a new UI team for AWS in Berlin. This made me curious about what they have in mind to do there and if this could be a fit for my current skill set. So I agreed to forward my resume to HR. The recruiter did a very good job and it was nice to communicate with him. Well, recruiters who actually read potential candidate profiles and write a personalised intro are super rare these days.
 As the next step I got a little bit of input on the hiring process in general. In short: “There will be 2 remote interviews. In case we like both a lot, there will be another 5–6. 1h each. Assuming you get there, we recommend to prepare for the 5–6 for at least 2 full weeks”.
 I realised that getting asked if I was interested was meaningless at this point and that I got dragged into the standard hiring process. My “being curious” trait kicked in and I was interested to see how their “Hire the best” process would be in real life.
 I was asked to use an online form to enter my preferred dates for the first remote interview. Inside this form, you can pick any time and any date (if I remember it correctly starting from 3 days ahead of the current day). The missing part was that the form / calendar view should display the available time ranges for each region and ideally block the times which are not available in case this is possible.
 I just picked the entire next week starting from 2pm until 10pm in CEST, since I was not sure if the calls would be US based. I got the response, that the interview times were 10am — 5pm in CEST and got asked to please enter new dates. I thought “well, this leaves 3 hours on 5 days in a row”, but went ahead to adjust my preferred dates inside the online calendar. There is no “Edit” button, so it is simply impossible to change them (Feature request!).
 I wrote an email back that i can make it happen to already start at 10am inside the full next week, in case this would make things easier for them. I got the response that there were no free spots inside the next week at all and got a slot for Monday June 22nd. This communication overhead could have been easily prevented in case the calendar view would have just shown me that the next week was blocked already (Feature request!).
 My first interview call was very nice and professional. The interviewer made a smart impression. The downside was that he was not allowed to tell me anything about the new team without signing an NDA first.
 Questions like: “Were there any significant contributions to the neo project from others since it went live?” or “If not many devs are using it yet, how can you be sure to be on the right way?”.
 Well, this did fit the Leadership Principles in a good way: “Because we do new things, we accept that we may be misunderstood for long periods of time.” and I liked that the interviewer actually looked into my project.
 One day later on Tuesday, June 23rd I got the email: “The team shared very positive feedback after the first conversation and would like to schedule a second phone interview with you.”. I was asked to pick my preferred dates for Round 2 within the next 3 weeks. I responded on the same day that Friday (June 26) would work as well as the entire following week. The initial Round 2 email contained the info, that Round 2 would be once more about Leadership Principles.
 On June 26, I got an email containing the “Amazon SDE Interview Prep”. This document is pretty much a buzzword-bingo of lots(!) of items which you get in touch with when studying computer sciences. There is no differentiation at all between Junior or Senior roles and most importantly there is no differentiation between Frontend and Backend related roles. To be clear: most items make no sense at all for Frontend related roles. So, this is probably my biggest feature request: please get more granular on this one. I did know a lot of the mentioned items 10–15 years ago, but the ones I never needed in real life projects afterwards are no longer present. I sent back an email right away (same day → Friday June 26) to double-check if my interviews are going to be frontend related and got a yes as the response. It was impossible to share real input due to NDAs, so the Prep Doc had literally zero value. I also mentioned that I got no feedback yet on my preferred dates for Round 2. I asked if we should sign an NDA for Round 2 and got the answer “No, this is not needed.”. Meaning: “We don’t care to provide you with any input which could be interesting for you.”.
 On Friday, July 3rd, I still got no input about my preferred dates for Round 2. My suggested dates were passed at this point and they included 42 hours inside the available CEST interview time. I am aware that HR employees probably got a lot on their plates, but just not responding at all after inviting me for a second round felt extremely unprofessional. There should be a candidate database in place with automated reminders to respond inside a reasonable time frame.
 To summarise my experience after being 1 full month into the process: 1) At this point I still had no date for Round 2, nor did I know if they even still wanted to do it. 2) I was expected to move from Munich to Berlin, in case the process would work out. 3) I got asked if I was interested in leading a new UI team and still had no clue about its mission (except from “We want to create the next generation of developer tools” which could be pretty much anything). 4) I had no clue if it is a good fit for my current skill set or covers topics which are interesting to me. 5) I got no input on the size of the new UI team (this one was important for me, since inside a small team I could continue developing on my own, which I deeply enjoy). 6) I got no input on the start date. 7) I got no salary related input.
 A bit thin, don’t you agree? My motivation was close to zero already.
 At this point I already turned down an offer from a different company. 6 figures & company shares, but not super interesting regarding the content.
 During the week, where I had time for Round 2, I got an email to please provide feedback on the Amazon Hiring process. I entered most parts of this article section there as well.
 On the Monday morning  after my preferred dates were passed, I got an email from Amazon:
  While looking for prospective candidates for career opportunities at Amazon, we found your profile on a publically available career website. Based on your professional background, we think you might be a good fit for job opportunities at Amazon and have added your details into our candidate relationship management system (“CRM-System”). This way, our internal recruitment team will be able to notify you when Amazon has job opportunities that we think you may be interested in. …”
 Well, it looks like the recruitment and HR teams are not using the same database :)
  “We are delighted to confirm your phone interview with Amazon Web Services on  Date: Tue, Jul 7, 2020 Time: 12:00pm — 1:00pm (CEST).”
 No apology for staying out of touch for 12 days, as well as ignoring my preferred dates. Expecting that I will make it happen to do a call on the next day.
 I wrote back to double-check if Round 2 was about the Leadership Principles again (as it was mentioned inside the initial Round 2 email) or about the Prep Doc (which could have been intended for the 5–6 interviews afterwards).
  The second interview felt like a joke to me. My interviewer made the impression of a Junior Dev with very little hiring experience. I asked him if he did take a look into my neo project before the call and got a “no”. I told him that there are more than 50.000 lines of my latest code out there which cover pretty much any topic on architectures, design patterns & algorithms and asked him if we should do a short 5–10m intro to get an impression of what I am capable of. “ No, it is just an open source project. If I wanted to, I could take a look at a later point.”.
 This made it very clear, that the interviewer was not interested at all in my professional skill set and had a curiosity close to zero. It also felt very arrogant, since I am pretty sure he would not be capable of understanding it without a short intro.
 Instead, my “challenge” (lol) was to show how I would re-create something like Google Analytics. My response was that I would create a script which can get included into Apps. Once loaded it could either use a WebSocket or transfer data via Ajax calls. I would just add one global click listener to the document.body, and send the delegated “JSONified” event paths (or ids & css rules → anything good enough to have an identifier where clicks happen). We could add buffering for mousemove events, in case those are relevant. I got the response that this was not sufficient, since they could use webcomponents and shadow dom is “off limits”. Actually it is not, since you can use the mode: “open” config on the shadow root to avoid this. It felt, like I lost him there (even googled it afterwards and I was correct). I also added that in case it would not be possible, we could just create hooks into the framework / library rendering logic and add separate click listeners for each webcomponent.
 I was smarter this time and asked, in case it was not possible to tell me anything again, if I could at least get some input on the UI tech stack they had in mind. Got some buzz words and it was underwhelming.
 On Wednesday, July 8, I got the email: “After careful consideration and review of your application, we have decided to progress with other candidates for this role.  While we are not able to provide additional feedback or information about this decision, we would like to keep in touch regarding future job opportunities.”.
  Probably for the best, since I assume it would have taken another 2+ weeks to get into the next round, once again not providing any input at all and doing more pointless tests.
     I know, we are in Covid-19 times and HR teams got a lot on their plates. Still, ignoring emails containing questions is incredibly unprofessional. Create Tools, in case they don’t exist, to track the communication with candidates. Add a big red flag & reminders in case there was no response.
 In case you don’t have time, just write a short email and let candidates know about it. Like: “Sorry, we are super busy at the moment, but we will get back to you next week.”.
  While big companies can allow themselves to be a bit arrogant (they really should not), since they do get a lot of applications, the story is different in case they use recruiters to reach out to potential candidates, especially for Senior roles.
 I talked to a lot of former colleagues and most of them would have quit the process much earlier with this little input. You will lose most of the best candidates otherwise.
 You can not expect a lot of input, testing & effort from candidates, without giving back. Why should someone invest a big amount of time without even knowing what for?
  So far, I have worked with > 2000 developers all around the globe. I am very familiar with my strengths & weaknesses. Trust me, 5–10 years ago this was not the case. Especially for Junior devs who put in all their heart & time into a hiring process, a statement like “ While we are not able to provide additional feedback or information about this decision” can be devastating. It is extremely unfair as well, since you don’t give candidates the chance to improve themselves.

  The goal is to check in general, if a candidate is able to admit mistakes (which is a good thing). You can also check if a candidate learned from mistakes and got better. “Try & fail” is a reasonable approach, especially in case you do learn & improve.
